channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: President Joe Biden pardons his son Hunter
item.description: The president said Sunday he had pardoned his son Hunter, who was found guilty of gun-related charges in Delaware and pleaded guilty to tax evasion in California. He said “raw politics has infected this process and it led to a miscarriage of justice.”

item.title: Mar-a-Lago becomes a magnet for foreign leaders, haunting Biden’s final acts
item.description: Declarations by President-elect Donald Trump that may or may not become policy have set some foreign governments on edge, while delighting others. Traditions to ensure a smooth transfer of power have been ignored.

item.title: They didn’t thank you for your gift. Our personal finance columnist suggests ways to talk it out.
item.description: They didn’t thank you for your gift. Our personal finance columnist suggests ways to talk it out.

item.title: The world fails to deliver a treaty on cleaning up plastic after marathon U.N. negotiations fall flat
item.description: Delegates from more than 170 countries meeting in South Korea failed to agree on how to curb plastic pollution. A broad coalition of nations pushed for manufacturing cuts, but oil-rich countries balked at the idea of limiting future plastics production. Negotiators said they hoped to continue the talks next year.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: Trump names Kash Patel as his choice to lead the FBI, an agency he has repeatedly criticized
item.description: FBI directors serve 10-year terms, so Donald Trump would have to fire Christopher Wray, or Wray would have to resign before his term is up in 2027. Patel has publicly mused about targeting journalists and government officials, and he published a list of “deep state” names in a book last year.

item.title: The 10 best books of 2024, according to The Post’s Book World staff
item.description: Expertly shaped fiction, brisk and original nonfiction: We've collected the year’s standouts.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: 59 gifts to surprise everyone on your list
item.description: From maximalist dog accessories to candles too pretty to burn, these gifts were selected for their quality, idiosyncrasy and charm.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Husband’s inability to stand up to parents isn’t okay anymore
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Husband’s inability to stand up to parents isn’t okay anymore

item.title: 15 recipes to give your Thanksgiving leftovers new life
item.description: 15 recipes to give your Thanksgiving leftovers new life

item.title: Do you know more about civics than an eighth-grader? Take our quiz.
item.description: Like millions of Americans, you probably have strong feelings about how the president should lead, what Congress should do and how the courts should rule, but do you know what gives them those powers in the first place? Test your knowledge to see if you know as much about government as a middle-schooler.

item.title: U.K. lawmakers back bill to legalize assisted dying in England and Wales, as more countries consider legalization
item.description:
The bill, modeled after Oregon’s law, would apply to terminally ill patients and could usher in one of the most dramatic social changes Britain has seen in years.
The bill still faces months of further scrutiny and procedural hurdles, but there’s a good chance of it becoming law.

item.title: 10 questions, plus a bonus wager! It’s the weekend edition of On the Record.
item.description: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

item.title: Notre Dame’s post-fire restoration is unveiled with a grand tour led by France’s Macron. See the first photos.
item.description: The tour is the first in-depth look inside since a 2019 fire gutted the cathedral. The tour celebrates the stonecutters, carpenters, sculptors and engineers who helped repair Notre Dame after French President Emmanuel Macron promised it would be rebuilt in five years.

item.title: Trump’s plans. Hostages in Gaza. Missing hiker found. Snow. Black Friday. Ancient footprints. Orcas vs. sharks. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Analysis: X is Elon Musk’s MAGA World. Threads is a mess. Is Bluesky any better?
item.description: Underneath the leadership of Musk, many people left X (formerly Twitter) with the digital equivalent of only the clothes on their back — abandoning their followings and taking only their usernames. Now the virtual town square is fragmented as people flee to bluer pastures.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: New job took care of the burnout. So why doesn’t it feel better?
item.description: Carolyn Hax: New job took care of the burnout. So why doesn’t it feel better?

item.title: Exercising to lose weight? Science says it rarely works.
item.description: A metabolism researcher dispels myths about how we burn calories and how this changes as we age.

item.title: Happy Thanksgiving! Play today's On the Record now.
item.description: Answer now to earn your Turkey Day points.

item.title: Bomb threats. Middle East. Prisoner swap. Thanksgiving forecast. NFL schedule. Weight loss. Stem cells. Catch up now.

item.title: These are America’s most fulfilling jobs, according to our Department of Data. One triumphed in a landslide.
item.description: What jobs give you the most satisfaction in life? Which ones make you feel like you're contributing to the community? Which make you proud of your employer? We looked at the data!

item.title: Is it better to roast a 20-pound turkey whole or cut it into parts? We’re answering your Thanksgiving cooking questions now.

item.title: Diamonds are forever, but this lab grows them in weeks
item.description: Lab-grown diamonds cost less and are more popular than ever. This is how they’re made.

item.title: Three Americans imprisoned in China have been released in a prisoner swap, according to U.S. officials
item.description: The three U.S. citizens — John Leung, Kai Li and Mark Swidan — will be reunited with their families soon, according to a White House statement. They had been wrongfully detained in China for years. It was not immediately clear who else was part of the trade.

item.title: A Thanksgiving myth in today's On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Wednesday points.

item.title: Israel-Hezbollah cease-fire. Trump’s tariffs. Captured fugitive. Organ donors. Vaccines. Cold weather. Orca video. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: For a low-stress Thanksgiving, get a head start on cooking with these make-ahead recipes for every part of your feast
item.description: Preparing the Thanksgiving feast can feel like a whirlwind. Lighten the load with our menu of make-ahead dishes, including green beans, mashed and sweet potatoes, mac and cheese, stuffing and, yes, even the turkey. Everything can be made ahead, if you want to.

item.title: Israel and Hezbollah have agreed to cease-fire deal, Biden says
item.description: The agreement, which passed a vote 10-1 in Israel's cabinet, takes effect on Wednesday at 4 a.m. local time and will pause a year-long conflict that has escalated in recent weeks, said U.S. and Israeli officials.

item.title: We crowdsourced D.C. winter snowfall forecasts. Here's what they say.
item.description: The hundreds of forecasts we gathered from readers, experts and our own Capital Weather Gang meteorologists project somewhat less snow than normal for the upcoming winter. Most people expect about a foot of snow compared to the normal amount, which is closer to 14 inches.

item.title: A columnist’s first 50 years: George F. Will looks back on five decades of writing
item.description: One secret of column-writing: Offer platoons of facts that give readers the delight of discovery.

item.title: Want to reduce Thanksgiving food waste? Give yourself permission to cook less.
item.description: Want to reduce Thanksgiving food waste? Give yourself permission to cook less.

item.title: Miss Manners: We host 2 holiday parties to accommodate all our friends
item.description: Miss Manners: We host 2 holiday parties to accommodate all our friends

item.title: These batteries could harness the wind and sun to replace coal and gas
item.description: New, hulking batteries can store enough renewable energy to replace polluting fossil fuel plants and power thousands of homes. Japan’s northernmost island, Hokkaido, is experimenting with technology that could help it power itself and export clean electricity to the rest of the country.

item.title: A not-so-jolly holiday season for this retailer
item.description: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points.

item.title: Trump’s tariffs. Jack Smith. Cease-fire talks. Macy’s expenses. Weight-loss drugs. Big batteries. Thanksgiving snow. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Biden administration proposes Medicare coverage of weight-loss drugs for millions of people, teeing up potential clash with RFK Jr.
item.description: The plan to pay for the popular anti-obesity medications for 7.5 million Medicare and Medicaid beneficiaries would cost the federal government tens of billions of dollars. But the incoming Trump administration could block the plan, and Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the president-elect’s choice for secretary of Health and Human Services, is an avowed enemy of the drugs.

item.title: Trump says he’ll impose new tariffs on Mexico, Canada and China, citing illegal immigration and drug smuggling
item.description: In a post on his social media site, the president-elect said he’d issue executive orders on his first day back in office, setting tariffs of 25 percent on imports from Mexico and Canada and 10 percent on imports from China.

item.title: Musk and Ramaswamy race to build a ‘DOGE’ team for war with Washington
item.description: Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy were tapped by President-elect Donald Trump to lead an advisory panel to find “drastic” cuts to the federal government. The two billionaire “Department of Government Efficiency” leaders have spent the past week in Washington and at Mar-a-Lago, seeking staff and interviewing seasoned political operators, legal specialists and top tech leaders, according to people familiar with the matter.

item.title: One game, endless fun. Introducing Wridges, our new word game. You’ll be hooked from the first letter.
item.description: One game, endless fun. Introducing Wridges, our new word game. You’ll be hooked from the first letter.

item.title: Jack Smith seeks to drop Trump from appeal of classified documents ruling but continue case against his two co-defendants
item.description: The motion, coming an hour after Smith moved to drop the Jan. 6 election obstruction case against Donald Trump, would allow the Justice Department to continue appealing Judge Aileen Cannon’s ruling that Smith was unlawfully appointed as special counsel. Smith is seeking to preserve what he can of the criminal cases, while acknowledging that federal policy prohibits prosecuting a sitting president.

item.title: Special counsel Jack Smith asks to dismiss Trump’s 2020 election obstruction case but allows case to be revived in future
item.description: The motion to dismiss charges without prejudice could put President-elect Donald Trump in the position of having to pardon himself before he leaves office to avoid future legal jeopardy.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: A cheater’s new fiancée wants to hear his ex’s side of the story
item.description: Carolyn Hax: A cheater’s new fiancée wants to hear his ex’s side of the story

item.title: Parts of your body start aging earlier than others, new research shows
item.description: Scientists call this new area of research “organ aging,” and it’s redefining how we think about getting older.

item.title: A TikTok take on a classic vegetable in today's On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: Barbara Taylor Bradford dies at 91. Her novels, mostly about resilient and wealthy women, have sold more than 90 million copies.
item.description: Bradford, a British-American novelist who debuted in 1979 with “A Woman of Substance,” a rags-to-riches tale that she followed with more than 30 bestsellers, died Sunday. Ten of her books were made into TV miniseries and films.

item.title: Trump picks. Israeli strike. Climate deal. Raw milk. Student death. ‘Glicked’ box office. Look-alike contest. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.
